message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Comprehensive Review of Recent Research Trends on Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs)
Paper Abstract: The growing interest in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) from both the scientific and industrial sectors has attracted a wave of new researchers and substantial investments in this expansive field. However, due to the wide range of topics and subdomains within UAV research, newcomers may find themselves overwhelmed by the numerous options available. It is therefore crucial for those involved in UAV research to recognize its interdisciplinary nature and its connections with other disciplines. This paper presents a comprehensive overview of the UAV field, highlighting recent trends and advancements. Drawing on recent literature reviews and surveys, the review begins by classifying UAVs based on their flight characteristics. It then provides an overview of current research trends in UAVs, utilizing data from the Scopus database to quantify the number of scientific documents associated with each research direction and their interconnections. This paper also explores potential areas for further development in UAVs, including communication, artificial intelligence, remote sensing, miniaturization, swarming and cooperative control, and transformability. Additionally, it discusses the development of aircraft control, commonly used control techniques, and appropriate control algorithms in UAV research. Furthermore, this paper addresses the general hardware and software architecture of UAVs, their applications, and the key issues associated with them. It also provides an overview of current open source software and hardware projects in the UAV field. By presenting a comprehensive view of the UAV field, this paper aims to enhance our understanding of this rapidly evolving and highly interdisciplinary area of research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Remote sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_sensing"},{"title":"Remote Sensing of Environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_Sensing_of_Environment"},{"title":"Indian Remote Sensing Programme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Remote_Sensing_Programme"},{"title":"Thermal remote sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_remote_sensing"},{"title":"Category:Remote sensing companies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Remote_sensing_companies"},{"title":"Radar remote sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radar_remote_sensing"},{"title":"International Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Society_for_Photogrammetry_and_Remote_Sensing"},{"title":"Remote sensing in geology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_sensing_in_geology"},{"title":"Remote Sensing (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_Sensing_(journal)"},{"title":"Dragon (remote sensing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dragon_(remote_sensing)"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Remote Sensing:

## Definition

Remote sensing is the acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon without making physical contact with the object, in contrast to in situ or on-site observation.(no content)The term is applied especially to acquiring information about Earth and other planets.

## Types of Remote Sensing

Remote sensing is divided into two main categories:

1. **Passive Remote Sensing**: Passive sensors gather radiation that is emitted or reflected by the object or surrounding areas, with reflected sunlight being the most common source of radiation measured by passive sensors.(no content)Examples of passive remote sensors include film photography, infrared, charge-coupled devices, and radiometers.

2. **Active Remote Sensing**: Active collection emits energy in order to scan objects and areas whereupon a sensor then detects and measures the radiation that is reflected or backscattered from the target.(no content)RADAR and LiDAR are examples of active remote sensing where the time delay between emission and return is measured, establishing the location, speed and direction of an object.

## Applications

Remote sensing makes it possible to collect data of dangerous or inaccessible areas, with applications including monitoring deforestation in areas such as the Amazon Basin, glacial features in Arctic and Antarctic regions, and depth sounding of coastal and ocean depths.(no content)Weather satellites are used in meteorology and climatology.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Types and Classifications

Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs). Additionally, an unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV), also known as a combat drone, fighter drone or battlefield UAV, is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that carries aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs on hardpoints or within weapons bay, allowing it to perform tactical attacks known as drone strikes.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier (the precursor to the aircraft carrier) in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These applications include surveillance, reconnaissance, search and rescue, infrastructure inspection, crop monitoring, and numerous other civilian and commercial purposes.

Web search results for query: "Open Source Software"

Links: [{"title":"Open-source software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_software"},{"title":"Free and open-source software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_and_open-source_software"},{"title":"List of formerly open-source or free software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_formerly_open-source_or_free_software"},{"title":"Comparison of open-source and closed-source software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_open-source_and_closed-source_software"},{"title":"Comparison of free and open-source software licenses - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_free_and_open-source_software_licenses"},{"title":"Open-source software movement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source-software_movement"},{"title":"History of free and open-source software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_free_and_open-source_software"},{"title":"Portal:Free and open-source software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Free_and_open-source_software"},{"title":"List of free and open-source software organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_free_and_open-source_software_organizations"},{"title":"Journal of Open Source Software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Open_Source_Software"}]

Here are the search results for "Open Source Software":

## Definition

Open-source software (OSS) is computer software that is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to use, study, change, and distribute the software and its source code to anyone and for any purpose.

## Key Characteristics

Open source puts very few restrictions on the use or distribution by any organization or user, in order to enable the rapid evolution of the software.(no content)Open-source licenses typically require that source code be made available without restrictions on modification or redistribution, and prohibit discrimination against individuals or groups.

## Benefits

Reasons for using FOSS include decreased software costs, increased security against malware, stability, privacy, opportunities for educational usage, and giving users more control over their own hardware.

## Development Model

Programmers participating in the open-source movement contribute to software development through voluntary collaboration and code sharing, with modifications typically shared with the broader community, creating a collaborative development process where contributions are tracked and attributed.

## Relationship to Free Software

FOSS is an inclusive umbrella term encompassing free software and open-source software.(no content)Although there is an almost complete overlap between free-software licenses and open-source-software licenses, there is a strong philosophical disagreement between the advocates of these two positions.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Definition

Open-source software (OSS) is computer software that is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to use, study, change, and distribute the software and its source code to anyone and for any purpose.

## Key Characteristics

Open source puts very few restrictions on the use or distribution by any organization or user, in order to enable the rapid evolution of the software.(no content)Open-source licenses typically require that source code be made available without restrictions on modification or redistribution, and prohibit discrimination against individuals or groups.

## Benefits

Reasons for using FOSS include decreased software costs, increased security against malware, stability, privacy, opportunities for educational usage, and giving users more control over their own hardware.

## Development Model

Programmers participating in the open-source movement contribute to software development through voluntary collaboration and code sharing, with modifications typically shared with the broader community, creating a collaborative development process where contributions are tracked and attributed.

## Relationship to Free Software

FOSS is an inclusive umbrella term encompassing free software and open-source software.(no content)Although there is an almost complete overlap between free-software licenses and open-source-software licenses, there is a strong philosophical disagreement between the advocates of these two positions.

## Search Results for "Artificial Intelligence"

I found comprehensive information about Artificial Intelligence. Here's an overview of the key findings:

### Definition and Core Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

### History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

### Current Applications

AI has been implemented across numerous sectors:
- Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.
- A 2023 study found that generative AI increased productivity by 15% in contact centers. Another 2023 study found it increased productivity by up to 40% in writing tasks.

### Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

### Ethical and Practical Concerns

The ethics of artificial intelligence covers algorithmic biases, fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and regulation, particularly where systems influence or automate human decision-making.

Links: [{"title":"Scopus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopus"},{"title":"CiteScore - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CiteScore"},{"title":"Template:Scopus id - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Scopus_id"},{"title":"Citation index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_and_citation_database"},{"title":"Template:Scopus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Scopus"},{"title":"Scopus (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopus_(journal)"},{"title":"Scirus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scirus"},{"title":"Scopus (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopus_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Template:Scopus id/doc - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Scopus_id/doc"},{"title":"Template:Scopus/doc - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Scopus/doc"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Scopus Database:

## Overview

Scopus is a scientific abstract and citation database, launched by the academic publisher Elsevier as a competitor to older Web of Science in 2004.

## Scope and Coverage

Elsevier's Scopus database is considered as one of the two most trusted or authoritative sources of bibliometric data for peer-reviewed global research knowledge across disciplines.(no content)Journals in Scopus are reviewed for sufficient quality each year according to four numerical measures: h-Index, CiteScore, SJR (SCImago Journal Rank) and SNIP (source normalized impact per paper), and the journals listed in Scopus are considered to meet the requirement for peer review quality established by several research grant agencies.

## Quality Metrics

CiteScore of an academic journal is a measure reflecting the yearly average number of citations to recent articles published in that journal, and is produced by Elsevier, based on the citations recorded in the Scopus database.

## Features and Comparison

In terms of the structured query language search capabilities Scopus is somewhat more advanced than Web of Science: for example, WoS can perform only NEAR/n queries, Scopus can also do PRE/n queries.

The database requires a subscription to access full functionality.

Links: [{"title":"Aircraft flight control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_flight_control_system"},{"title":"List of United States Air Force aircraft control and warning squadrons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_Air_Force_aircraft_control_and_warning_squadrons"},{"title":"Category:Command and control aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Command_and_control_aircraft"},{"title":"915th Aircraft Control and Warning Squadron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/915th_Aircraft_Control_and_Warning_Squadron"},{"title":"Dual control (aviation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_control_(aviation)"},{"title":"Flight control surfaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_control_surfaces"},{"title":"Flight control modes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_control_modes"},{"title":"Control line - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_line"},{"title":"Air traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_traffic_control"},{"title":"Category:United States command and control aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:United_States_command_and_control_aircraft"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Aircraft Control:

## Aircraft Flight Control Systems

A conventional fixed-wing aircraft flight control system consists of flight control surfaces, the respective cockpit controls, connecting linkages, and the necessary operating mechanisms to control an aircraft's direction in flight.

### Primary Control Surfaces

A conventional fixed-wing aircraft uses three primary flight control surfaces– aileron, rudder and elevator to control the roll, yaw, and pitch respectively. These surfaces work by manipulating the aircraft's movement along three axes:

- **Pitch**: Pitch changes the vertical direction that the aircraft's nose is pointing, and elevators are the primary flight control surfaces used to control the pitch.

- **Roll**: The longitudinal axis passes through the aircraft from nose to tail, and the rotation about this axis is termed as roll, with ailerons as the primary control surfaces to effect this.

- **Yaw**: The vertical axis passes through an aircraft from top to bottom, and the rotation about this axis is called yaw.

### Types of Control Systems

Mechanical or manually operated flight control systems are the most basic method of controlling an aircraft and were used in early aircraft and are currently used in small aircraft where the aerodynamic forces are not excessive.

For modern aircraft, Airbus aircraft designs after the A300/A310 are almost completely controlled by fly-by-wire equipment, with flight controls on the Airbus A330, for example, being all electronically controlled and hydraulically activated.

- **Pitch**: Pitch changes the vertical direction that the aircraft's nose is pointing, and elevators are the primary flight control surfaces used to control the pitch.

- **Roll**: The longitudinal axis passes through the aircraft from nose to tail, and the rotation about this axis is termed as roll, with ailerons as the primary control surfaces to effect this.

- **Yaw**: The vertical axis passes through an aircraft from top to bottom, and the rotation about this axis is called yaw.

### Types of Control Systems

Mechanical or manually operated flight control systems are the most basic method of controlling an aircraft and were used in early aircraft and are currently used in small aircraft where the aerodynamic forces are not excessive.

For modern aircraft, Airbus aircraft designs after the A300/A310 are almost completely controlled by fly-by-wire equipment, with flight controls on the Airbus A330, for example, being all electronically controlled and hydraulically activated.

Web search results for query: "Swarming Robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Talk:Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Marco Dorigo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marco_Dorigo"},{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Boids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boids"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Shield AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shield_AI"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Swarm Robotics:

## Overview

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, and is an approach to the coordination of multiple robots as a system which consist of large numbers of mostly simple physical robots.

## Key Principles

Robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities such as wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s. One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, in which a swarm of up to 20 robots capable of independently physically connecting to each other were used to study swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments and solve complex mazes via onboard sensors. Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, for instance mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

## Design Characteristics

Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach to achieve meaningful behavior at swarm-level through a greater number of interactions.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Control Theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability; often with the aim to achieve a degree of optimality.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics. Beyond engineering, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

## Web Search Results: Cooperative Control Multi-agent

Here are the key findings from the search on cooperative control in multi-agent systems:

### Core Concepts

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents that can solve problems which are difficult or impossible for an individual agent to solve.(no content)In pure cooperation settings, agents receive the exact same rewards and play with each other.(no content)Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is used to explore how separate agents with identical interests can communicate and work together.

### Cooperative Planning and Coordination

Multiagent planning can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.(no content)In computing, cooperative distributed problem solving is a network of semi-autonomous processing nodes working together to solve a problem, typically in a multi-agent system.

### Collaborative Control Theory

Collaborative Control Theory (CCT) is a collection of principles and models for supporting effective design of collaborative e-work systems, and advances in artificial intelligence, multi-agent systems, and cyber physical systems have enabled cyber-supported collaboration in highly distributed organizations of people, robots, and autonomous systems.(no content)Cooperation involves all aspects of coordination as well as a resource-sharing dimension to support goal achievement, and commonly exhibits a division of labor component among participants.

### Applications

Research topics in multi-agent systems include cooperation and coordination, multi-agent learning, robotics and multi-robot systems.

## Web Search Results: Cooperative Control Multi-agent

Here are the key findings from the search on cooperative control in multi-agent systems:

### Core Concepts

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents that can solve problems which are difficult or impossible for an individual agent to solve.(no content)In pure cooperation settings, agents receive the exact same rewards and play with each other.(no content)Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is used to explore how separate agents with identical interests can communicate and work together.

### Cooperative Planning and Coordination

Multiagent planning can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.(no content)In computing, cooperative distributed problem solving is a network of semi-autonomous processing nodes working together to solve a problem, typically in a multi-agent system.

### Collaborative Control Theory

Collaborative Control Theory (CCT) is a collection of principles and models for supporting effective design of collaborative e-work systems, and advances in artificial intelligence, multi-agent systems, and cyber physical systems have enabled cyber-supported collaboration in highly distributed organizations of people, robots, and autonomous systems.(no content)Cooperation involves all aspects of coordination as well as a resource-sharing dimension to support goal achievement, and commonly exhibits a division of labor component among participants.

### Applications

Research topics in multi-agent systems include cooperation and coordination, multi-agent learning, robotics and multi-robot systems.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Miniaturization Electronics"

Links: [{"title":"Miniaturization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miniaturization"},{"title":"Process miniaturization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_miniaturization"},{"title":"Molecular electronics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_electronics"},{"title":"Microfabrication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microfabrication"},{"title":"2 nm process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/20A_process"},{"title":"Nanoelectromechanical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanoelectromechanical_systems"},{"title":"Microbotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbot"},{"title":"TE Connectivity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyco_Electronics"},{"title":"Microtechnology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microtechnology"},{"title":"AAA battery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AAA_batteries"}]

I've completed a web search for "Miniaturization Electronics". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Miniaturization is the trend to manufacture ever-smaller mechanical, optical, and electronic products and devices.(no content)Examples include miniaturization of mobile phones, computers and vehicle engine downsizing.

## Historical Development

The technology progressed from vacuum tubes to transistors in the 1950s and then to integrated circuits. The MOSFET was invented at Bell Labs between 1955 and 1960 and was the first truly compact transistor that could be miniaturized and mass-produced for a wide range of uses.(no content)This made it possible to build high-density IC chips, with reduced cost-per-transistor as transistor density increased.

## Manufacturing Processes

Microfabrication is the process of fabricating miniature structures of micrometre scales and smaller.(no content)In the last two decades, microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), microsystems and their subfields have re-used, adapted or extended microfabrication methods, including microfluidics/lab-on-a-chip, optical MEMS, RF MEMS, PowerMEMS, BioMEMS and their extension into nanoscale systems.

## Current Progress

TSMC began risk production of its 2 nm process in July 2024, with mass production planned for the second half of 2025, and Samsung plans to start production in 2025.

## Advanced Technologies

Molecular electronics is the study and application of molecular building blocks for electronic components, spanning physics, chemistry, and materials science, and provides a potential means to extend Moore's Law beyond the foreseen limits of conventional silicon integrated circuits.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Analysis Complete ✅

2. **Artificial intelligence** - For UAV autonomy and decision-making
3. **Remote sensing** - Major application domain for UAVs
4. **Swarm robotics** - Multi-UAV cooperative systems
5. **Multi-agent system** - Framework for UAV coordination
6. **Aircraft flight control system** - Core UAV control technology
7. **Control theory** - Mathematical foundation for UAV algorithms
8. **Scopus** - Database used to quantify research trends
9. **Open-source software** - Development tools and platforms
10. **Miniaturization** - Technology for smaller, efficient UAVs

- ✅ Classified with appropriate entity types (task, concept, method, tool)
